columns.text: In this problem, we will use the concept of adjusted cash flow from assets to solve for the price per share of the company's stock.

In this problem, we first need to solve for the free cash flow. The free cash flow can be solved using this formula:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Free cash flow}&=\text{EBIT}\times (1-\text{Tax rate})+\text{Depreciation}\\
&-\text{Net working capital}-\text{Capital spending}
\end{aligned}$$

From the previous problem, the values are:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{EBIT}&=\$1,800,000\\
\text{Tax rate}&=0.21\\
\text{Depreciation}&=\$155,000\\
\text{Net working capital}&=\$75,000\\
\text{Capital spending}&=\$115,000
\end{aligned}$$

Substituting the values above, our free cash flow will be:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Free cash flow}&=\$1,800,000 \times (1-0.21)+\$155,000\\
&-\$75,000-\$115,000\\[15 pt]
&=\$1,387,000
\end{aligned}$$

The free cash flow of the company is $\$1,387,000$.

We can then solve for the cash flow for the succeeding years by taking the cash flow from the previous year and multiplying it to one plus the growth rate which is $18\%$.

For Year 1, the cash flow for this is the free cash flow which is $\$1,387,000$.

For the succeeding years:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Cash flow for Year 2}&=\$1,387,000 \times (1+0.18)\\
&=\$1,636,660\\[15 pt]

\text{Cash flow for Year 3}&=\$1,636,660 \times (1+0.18)\\
&=\$1,931,258.80\\[15 pt]

\text{Cash flow for Year 4}&=1,931,258.80 \times (1+0.18)\\
&=\$2,278,885.38\\[15 pt]

\text{Cash flow for Year 5}&=\$2,278,885.38 \times (1+0.18)\\
&=\$2,689,084.75
\end{aligned}$$

Additionally, we will take the sales in Year 5 and multiply it to the price-sales ratio of $1.9$. The sales in Year 5 is valued at $\$16,900,000$.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Cash flow for Year 5}&=\$2,689,084.75+(\$16,900,000 \times 1.9)\\
&=\$34,799,084.75
\end{aligned}$$

Solving for the present values, we get:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Present value for Year 1}&=\$1,387,000 \times \left(\dfrac{1}{1+0.085}\right)^1\\[15 pt]
&=\$1,278,341.01\\[15 pt]

\text{Present value for Year 2}&=\$1,636,660 \times \left(\dfrac{1}{1+0.085}\right)^2\\[15 pt]
&=\$1,390,269.49\\[15 pt]

\text{Present value for Year 3}&=\$1,931,258.80 \times \left(\dfrac{1}{1+0.085}\right)^3\\[15 pt]
&=\$1,511,998.16\\[15 pt]

\text{Present value for Year 4}&=\$2,278,885.38 \times \left(\dfrac{1}{1+0.085}\right)^4\\[15 pt]
&=\$1,644,385.09\\[15 pt]

\text{Present value for Year 5}&=\$34,799,084.75 \times \left(\dfrac{1}{1+0.085}\right)^5\\[15 pt]
&=\$23,142,972.05\\
\end{aligned}$$

To get the value of the firm, we will add the present values.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Value of the firm}&=\$1,278,341.01+\$1,390,269.49\\
&+\$1,511,998.16+\$1,644,385.09\\
&+\$23,142,972.05\\[15 pt]
&=\$28,967,965.80
\end{aligned}$$

The firm's value is $\$28,967,965.80$.

Now, to get the price per share of the company's stock, we can simply take the value of the company and divide it by the number of outstanding shares which is $750,000$.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Price per share}&=\dfrac{\$28,967,965.80}{750,000}\\[15 pt]
&=\$38.62
\end{aligned}$$

The price per share of the company's stock is $\$38.62$.
